member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.Utilities.Parameters.Implementation.Direct.Pointers
member.summary:
Corresponding directly to , this is the value of what each path pointed to.
Please note that choosing between one of these for the "right value" to read from is a non-problem. Think of a direct's paths like a list of instructions. If I tell you to write your name on 5 different papers, your name isn't going to change between those pages, so if I need to find your name, I can pick any page I want and still get the right value. Likewise, you can pick anything out of this and it'll be the "right value" you are looking for.
If you are feeling particularly indecisive, you can just reference .
If you need to set the values however, overriding all entries is required, and this can be done with .

member.name: T:ThreeRingsSharp.Utilities.Parameters.Implementation.Direct.DirectPointer
member.summary:
Points to a value pointed at by a . This is, hence its name, best compared to a pointer.
When a Direct in OOO points to something's value, that Direct becomes a means of reading and writing to that value. As such, this class aims to mirror that behavior in the most minimal way possible. This class does not care about the path or parameters that stand between the model and its affected property. This class exclusively provides access to the value.
Note that this behaves as more than a simple container, as it actually modifies the value on the model if you change it through this class.

member.name: T:ThreeRingsSharp.Utilities.ReadFileContext
member.summary:
Represents the context of an opened file. Since files may be read in a chain (that is, file A might reference B and C, which reference D, E, F, and G, so on), this contains the cumulative data of all read operations for every file together. A new instance of this should be created and passed in when reading data out of a acquired from a .
This class additionally manages the data tree display once the model has loaded. To do this, it uses a stack-based methodology to add items to the tree. Remember that there are two trees in TRS, one for the loaded models, and the other for the properties of a given loaded model.

member.name: T:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.MeshData
member.summary:
Represents mesh data. This is referenced by s to determine their mesh data.
In order to prevent formats that support unqiue objects from exporting the same mesh more than once, this class is used.
This allows multiple objects to represent the same mesh data rather than recreating it for every individual instance of the model.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.MeshData.BoneNames
member.summary:
A list of every bone name in this model that deforms the model (so NOT all of the bones)! Unlike the list provided in Clyde geometry, the first element (index 0) of this list is null.
This allows easier bone indexing when observing vertex groups since all that needs to be done is testing if the name is null (0 denotes "not in a bone group")

member.summary: The native ushort index array from the model that instantiated this mesh without any processing.

member.summary: The native float weight array from the model that instantiated this mesh without any processing.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.MeshData.HasBoneData
member.summary:
This should be if this has bone data. If it is false, will not do anything.
Ensure this is only set to if , , and are all populated properly.
As a temporary fix for a number of issues caused by armors, this property's { ; } will only be able to return if all of the data associated with bones is correct (so setting it to without correct data will cause this to still return ).

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.MeshData.UsesExternalRoot
member.summary:
If , this mesh didn't come with a root node (wasn't an ArticulatedConfig) which means that it likely uses a different model for its root.
This is observable in knights, where the main knight model provides the skeleton, and then the other meshes attach to that skeleton but otherwise have their own vertex groups.
Unfortunately, keeping track of that root is not very easy, because we don't actually know hat it is when this MeshData is instantiated.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Model3D.MultiplyScaleByHundred
member.summary:
Multiplies the scale of exported models by 100. This is really handy for a lot of models but may cause others to be huge.
This is by default since it's used more than it isn't.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Model3D.ProtectAgainstZeroScale
member.summary:
If , any models that have a scale of zero will have their scale corrected. Cases where models are dubbed incorrect are:
- The matrix's scale (a ) only has its X value populated, Y and Z are zero. Y and Z will be set to X (this happens for cases where uniform scale is stored as a Vector3f)
- The matrix's scale has a magnitude of zero.
- The method returns zero, in which case, if the matrix has a non-zero uniform scale it will be set to this, or it will be directly set to 1.

Unlike , this does not contain any vector math methods. This is strictly for data storage.

member.name: T:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Structs.VertexGroup
member.summary: Represents a vertex group, which is used for rigged models. All stored vertices simply represent a vertex that has a weight in a given bone group. As such, if a vertex has a weight value less than 1, it will be a duplicate of at least one other vertex in one other vertex group.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Structs.VertexGroup.Vertices
member.summary: All of the vertices stored in this VertexGroup, which all correspond to a specific bone. These ARE unique objects (not unique positions in space) since this is a representation of bone data. If you need to access the full geometry (and not every vertex used by a given bone), do it through . Do note that Weights are stored within vertices.

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Structs.VertexGroup.Indices
member.summary: The indices in this vertex group. These form triangles in this .

member.name: P:ThreeRingsSharp.XansData.Structs.VertexGroup.IndexIndices
member.summary:
The indices of elements in the parent . This is probably confusing to read, so think of it this way:
I access a value out of this list. The returned value int returnedValue = IndexIndices[x] is used to index the parent's data arrays (Indices, Vertices, Bone stuff): Parent.Indices[returnedValue]. Make more sense?

member.summary:
Asynchronously show a message box (show a message box without causing the GUI to stop updating, allowing stuff to work in the background).
This also allows the user to interact with the GUI before closing the message box, as a side effect.
This task will return if is !
member.param: The text to display in the body of the message box.
The title displayed at the top of the message box.
The buttons used in the message box (e.g. OK)
